comments.commentBody:
Which New Yorkers are burned out?
Not the ones who live in parts of Brooklyn or East Harlem that were uninhabitable prior to community policing. Now they can park their cars without chains and 3 alarms and walk home safely, perhaps buy something from a store that doesn't bang down the iron gates at 4PM.

Stealing? It's not Lhota who will start with a tax hike on January 1st. The 'rich' corporations have added 60,000 jobs this year alone, they pay most of the taxes in NYC which allows the government to keep us safe and expand services.

Waging war on one class is the fast way to ruin, ask Detroit- the high tax-payers can easily move away.

Chicklet: My old neighborhood in the Bronx is mostly "uninhabitable" now because of the exorbitant rise in rents where crime has not gone down nearly as much as rents have gone up( crime statistics can and have been manipulated). I agree with some of the other comments that there are many other things that have happened in the last 20+ years that have resulted in real crime being lower; basically, that the city's people are different now in lots of ways. 20 something years is a long time, the entire culture of the City is different  and that cannot be blamed on or credited to any particular mayor. If it matters now,  "Community Policing"( basically getting cops out of radio cars and walking a beat), was started by Dave Dinkin's police Comm. Lee Brown, that is when the City began to turn the corner on violent crime, a fact that is rarely reported.

Fed Up - the problem with your argument is that the 1% to 99% notion is wrong outside of the Wall Street debacle of 2008. The 99% in no way share the same interests.

A large part of the 99% are middle class taxpayers who pay for the social services of those who can't work, can't find work, or won't work.
When DeBlasio talks of an activist government the middle class/working class ducks for cover, as they recognize the code for, "We'll take more from your paycheck!"

Just by Giuliani's comment that he and Lhota have similar political philosophies will guarantee that the Republican candidate will lose.  New Yorkers are burned out on the stealing from the poor and giving to the rich modus operandi, along with a government for the one percenters, of the one percenters and by the one percenters.
New York is heading in neither the Giuliani or Dinkins direction. New York is headed to where ever the people decide it's heading. No more glass condos, no more squeegee men, no more nonsense.
The trouble with medicine is that the placebo effect is very effective and the longer the remedy has been around the stronger the placebo effect becomes.

Eh, this pseudo science stuff never seems to go anywhere. For me the real long term test of a scientific idea is that it accumulates evidence and strength over time and leads to every increasing number of new ideas. Most of this other stuff just sits there forever, pretending to be scientific.

In India, we have Unani, Siddha, Naturopathy, Acupressure, Acupuncture, Reiki apart from Ayurveda when we look at non-conventional way of treating diseases. The key difference between Allopathy and other forms of medicine is on diagnosis. In allopathy form of medicine we have structured a sequential way of diagnosis for normal functioning of the body, for every abnormality or anamoly we try to rectify by using chemicals or by surgery.

Whereas in Oriental medicine, the diagnosis is not sequential it is iterative, we can diagnose through pulse, color of nails, eys, tounge and palm, we can also diagnose from stomach, chest, nose, ears temperature, we can also diagnose from the patients likeness and dislikes....in fact, Oriental way of diagnosis has great advantages inherent to its time tested lineage of thousands and thousands years of fault adjustments in diagnosing patients. Also one great advantage is Oriental system will adapt to local conditions of the disease.

I am not suggesting that Oriental Medicine is a cure all method for every kind of disease, there are numerous diseases which are cured very easily compared to Allopathy, there are far too easier ways to diagnose disease and suggest physical proof of disease through clinical laboratory. There are far too many ways to predict a disease in Oriental medicine compared to allopathy.

The solution is only in combining the best of the worlds and provide the most effective way to treat the disease. - Divaker V Vittal
But be careful with your character count and don't let it slip that liberal economists are allowed to use Obamas allotment of extra characters.
DVR, set! Thank you. You should give your readers a heads up here and on Twitter...

MTF, I bet you thought Martin didn't have a sense of humor.  The two people who regularly post here with a hidden sense of humor are Martin and Laszlo. When it rears its funny head it usually comes with a zinger. Yesterday Laszlo welcomed Howie into his web and today you are the lucky one who Martin favors.  Feel honored.
Not only that, they should not be allowed to do anything else but vote to restore funding.
Weight loss? I thought he meant clean shaven.
Sounds good.  You have looked a bit florid at times so a bit of weight loss and some exercise would be good.

Anyone who thinks that gaming isn't a sport should go watch a video of a Korean Starcraft player at the keyboard and ask themselves if a Nascar driver could come anywhere close to matching that level of movement speed.

Some of the comments are quite uninformed unfortunately.

Esports, or competitive video gaming, has literally everything that traditional sports have nowadays: teams, leagues, tournaments, major tournaments, coaches, recognized bodies which "supervise and regulate games", corporate sponsorship, shows and other media coverage reviewing games, discussing strategy and/or interviewing players etc, fanbases, casters, hosts/moderators, journalists, pre/post match interviews, injuries, team websites and others devoted solely to esports, gear and merchandise, even cheerleaders and scandals. The list goes on. Esports is strikingly similar to traditional sports, the only real difference is the competition takes place on the computer. Like Alex Garfield said, when people don't accept this it's usually because they don't think it's legitimate/cool enough, i.e. it's their opinion, or they're uninformed.

In South Korea, where esports is much older and culturally accepted, Starcraft has practically been a national sport since before 2000. The video really doesn't do the actual magnitude of the competition and viewership justice. Tournaments hosted by MLG and others such as IEM and Dreamhack in Europe are routinely jampacked with thousands of viewers in arenas, with hundreds of thousands more watching remotely, just like in traditional sports.

Take some time to learn about the esports world. You might be amazed at what you find.

Although USA may not recognize gaming as sports, Asia has labeled gaming competition as e-sports: electronic sports. South Korea is famous for this since the release of Starcraft. It's such a big industry that they even hold the final match in world cup stadium.

Tell that to the over one million concurrent viewers of The International 3, a recent major tournament for Dota 2.

People don't generally want to watch other people play videogames? Ha.
Probably no more than 2 innings.  Per game.
Does this mean you're happy the Yanks didn't make the playoffs?  Some fan.
Sounds like Rivera's arm is bad enough that Had the Yankees made the playoffs, Rivera may not have been able to pitch.
My heart  aches , knowing an era has indeed ended. Though I'm sad for myself, I'm happy for Mariano and Andy - they went out on top - something that can be hard for  an athlete to do.

I will think of the 2014 season and beyond as not "empty without them", but rather as an opportunity to smile and, when seeing some pitcher or reliever have a great game, be able to say, "Yeah, that was good, but I remember when Pettitte did this, or Rivera did that..."  Guys with class never are gone from the game.  And two great sportsmen showed us class.
What memorable endings to two illustrious careers that exemplified the greatness of baseball and the strength of their characters.  2014 will be empty without them -
This is why we love the game.

Did you read the NYT article a few months ago about taking time off, such as your wife did, detracts from earnings and career achievement, often in ways that are not repairable? Being a housewife may or may not be oppressive, but it certainly does have a cost. It's up to the individual whether that cost is acceptable.

No it won't. Most American female golfers are lucky to be competitive in a rapidly improving international game. It's doubtful that a mid-level player could take time off to be a professional spouse/try to keep her husband from cheating and then pick up where she left off when she chose to get back to golf.

Actually, these gaming houses have very regular physical excercise routines in addition to the game training, which both the coaches and the players say allows the players to focus and maximize their training.  It was a pretty major oversight in the article.
Maybe Iran would recognize Israel if Israel got rid of its nuclear and chemical weapons...   Fat chance.

Peace is important for Israel too. Unless Israel is worried about its arms businesses and their new drilling off of Syria. How can peace hurt Israel? This isn't about protecting the Jewish people. This is business interests pure and simple.
Excellent questions, Stu. Perhaps we should raise them with our other regional ally, the Saudis.

A pity that Mr. Friedman didn't think to ask the Iranians about issues apart from the nuclear stand-off.  What's their real answer to questions about the Holocaust?  What did Rouhani say and not say?  What did he mean and not mean?  Also: would Iran ever conceive of recognizing the state of Israel if, at some point, a peace deal brought about the existence of a Palestinian state?  To the extent that our government seems unable to act in its own bests interests in that part of the world without getting a go-ahead from the Israelis, we might just as well try to alleviate some of their concerns relative to Iran's appreciation of both the past and the future of the Jewish people.

It's a cliche, but -- correlation isn't causation! Some diseases can go into remission, for reasons known or unknown. The hypnotist could just as well have shaken a rattle or boiled the head of a frog, it would have had the same supposed" effect."

The Catholic Church has long taken advantage of remission, ascribing a cured case of cancer, say, to the intercession of a saint. What they neglect to mention of course is that a certain percentage of usually-lethal cancers will resolve on their own (actually be destroyed the immune system), and that this is true whether one worships or not.

Pseudoscience embraces such coincidences and calls them "evidence." Science uses statistics and controls experimental variables to get better results.

Since we are sharing anecdotes about non-traditional medicine and its effects, I will offer up my favorite, concerning a patient with a terrible and 100 percent fatal skin disease that grotesquely altered the physical appearance of the its victim. He presented himself to a young doctor who had become interested in hypnotherapy. With no good alternatives available to him, the doctor hypnotized the poor, suffering patient, telling him that the left side of his body would miraculously cure itself. In a short time, the patient reappeared in the doctor's office with the left side of his body completely free of disease. Impressed, the young doctor called in his much older and supposedly wiser colleague, who was astounded. He said there was no record of any remission of this disease. This is impossible, he said. The young doctor now felt even better at what he had accomplished. So he hypnotized the patient again and said the right side would now be cured. Meanwhile, hearing of this miraculous cure, other doctors began using hypnosis with victims. Not only did none of the other patients respond, but the treatment also failed with the one patient who had previously responded. What had the young doctor done that first time that he was never able to repeat? And why did the patient who believed in the cure fail to respond a second time? His faith in the treatment could not have been shaken because he never heard the opinion of the older doctor.
So thoughtfully and nicely said.

When those four eggs meet your husband's sperm, they may or may not fertilize and begin to divide into cells properly.  You may get only one or two (or no) embryos to implant.  But you wanted mini-IVF, so you already know this.
I went to college 5,000 miles away from my parents and it was great - I spent summers with them, and there were no "emergencies" that American helicopter parents like to fret over.

Actually, many religious folks (especially Catholics) are opposed to IVF. If you believe that life begins at conception, then it follows that IVF is problematic for all the embryos that are created and not given the chance to become life.

On a related note, many Protestants (especially evangelicals) are leading a movement for "embryo adoption," where unused embryos are frozen and then "adopted" by other couples.

Sometimes those couples are infertile. Sometimes they are not but see it as a way to give unborn children a chance.

Disclaimer: I'm pro-choice and not Christian...just surprised that someone thinks that the anti-abortion folk aren't concerned about fertility issues, when, in fact, many of them are.

Most embryos never become babies; they either never implant or are lost to miscarriages (many of which happen so early the woman doesn't even know it--but if she's an IVF patient she knows it because she's being monitored so closely).

A "good grade" embryo is an embryo between 2 and 5 days old that is behaving like a healthy embryo of that age (the stages of healthy embryonic development are known and very clear). Such embryos are more likely to be capable of growing into a baby. When I say capable, I mean genetically capable--they're more likely to have the right number of chromosomes to develop into a full-term infant. When choosing which embryos to transfer into a patient's womb, doctors preferentially choose these embryos.

If a patient is old enough that transferring 3 or 4 embryos is recommended, and she only has--say--two good-grade embryos, doctors might suggest adding one or two not-so-good embryo because those embryos also have a chance (though a smaller one) of developing into babies. Keep in mind here that we're talking about a chance on the order of, say, 30% for each good-grade embryo and 10% for each non-good grade embryo; putting in two good ones and two dodgier-looking ones often ends in no pregnancy at all but still slightly ups the chances of a baby relative to just putting in the two good ones.

To complete that post... if the patient is too young for transferring 3 or 4 (the younger you are the higher the risk of multiples), or is old enough but doesn't want to take the (minuscule) risk of triplets or quads, then the doctors will generally transfer the two good ones, let the others keep growing in their petri dishes until they stop (i.e. die), or if they don't stop, then on day 5 the doctors will generally freeze them for future attempts at pregnancy.

This describes what happens when genetic testing is not used. It's usually not used because the technology for it is expensive. When it is used, embryos are grown to day 5 (most of the non-good grade ones stop growing before then) and then tested to see which ones are actually capable of making a baby. The ones that are genetically okay are used or frozen for future use, and the ones that are not okay are discarded or used for research.

Many religious people oppose IVF because they believe each embryo can become a baby and thus it's wrong not to use all embryos. They're wrong, since most embryos are either not genetically capable of becoming a baby or are not going to implant. Case in point: if you do CCS testing, the most advanced and accurate genetic testing available today, and it tells you that a given embryo is genetically healthy, that embryo still only has a 60% chance of becoming a baby. In other words, for every 10 healthy embryos that you transfer into a woman's womb, only 6 will become babies.

I do not understand why people who are strongly opposed to abortion are in favor of fertility programs.  Does the mention of a "good grade" embryo mean something different to them than it does to other people?  What happens to an embryo that is not of a good grade?  And what happens to all the embryos that are not used?
I sat next to a 19-year old who was tsk-tsking about some poor baby with an earache a few rows away.  I said to him, "you were a baby yourself once, you know."  He stopped tsking.
